channel.title: Creating a boot program?
channel.description: I'm interested in creating a program that runs all by itself (no operating system, run on a CD). What (things) do I need to learn to create a boot-up program?

item.title: Creating a boot program?
item.dc:creator: @Rajae Rajae
item.description:
@Rajae wrote:

Haven’t thought of that, but that’s a smart way of testing my os.

Read full topic

item.title: Creating a boot program?
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

IIRC, you can use the VMware player for testing your os.

Read full topic

item.title: Creating a boot program?
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

Linux would help here, although it’s a lot easier if you had a floppy drive (since you could just compile your shit, do “dd if=./compile of/dev/floppy” and reboot)

Read full topic

item.title: Creating a boot program?
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“Rajae, post:6, topic:190899”]I see, so I need to learn the Assembly language.

Now, how would I make the Assembly code run off a CD after choosing to boot from it?[/quote]
No freaking clue. Take a look at the Ubuntu Live CD source code, if you can find it.

Read full topic

item.title: Creating a boot program?
item.dc:creator: @Rajae Rajae
item.description:
@Rajae wrote:

I see, so I need to learn the Assembly language.

Now, how would I make the Assembly code run off a CD after choosing to boot from it?

item.title: Creating a boot program?
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“Rajae, post:3, topic:190899”][quote author=lawl link=topic=254460.msg2121432#msg2121432 date=1205986435]
assembly
[/quote]
Are you serious, I must learn 0110000101110011011100110110010101101101011000100110110001111001?

Nothing more easier like Java or C++?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: March 19, 2008, 05:20:26 PM[/size][hr][quote author=Mopman link=topic=254460.msg2121441#msg2121441 date=1205986695]
You could write it in anything native really, with a little bootstrap in assembly (srsly, it’s really simple shit, you wouldn’t need to become any sort of decent asm programmer to do it)
[/quote]
I’ll look into that.[/quote]
Well if you actually wanted to code using x86 opcodes, I suppose you would need to know binary…but you don’t want to do that. We’re talking about assembly.
“It implements a symbolic representation of the numeric machine codes and other constants needed to program a particular CPU architecture.”

Read full topic

item.title: Creating a boot program?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Uh… binary is piss easy. You might want to pick it up before trying to write your own OS, also, since it’s a fundemental part of how your computer works.

Read full topic

item.description:

assembly

Are you serious, I must learn 0110000101110011011100110110010101101101011000100110110001111001?
